headers.text: Hope Amidst Hunger: Timor Leste’s Pursuit of a Brighter Future
Reflections on key challenges to overcome in Timor Leste for a successful Integrated Management of Acute Malnutrition (IMAM)

paragraphs.text: Despite its’ legacy of decades of conflict, Timor Leste has made significant progress in several sectors; health, education, infrastructure and financial growth among them. Well known for its incredible natural resources and certainly one of the most resilient societies I have ever come across, Timor faces many challenges when moving towards sustainable economic growth and human development. Maluk Timor, a health care organization based in Dili, focuses on capacity building and it places particular emphasis on wasting treatment. CMAM practices are integrated within the primary health care system and run by the government. There are numerous gaps and challenges our team faces, nevertheless many strengths need to be acknowledged. Such complexities should be seen as an opportunity to make a lasting positive impact in the acute malnutrition setting.

Timor Leste, a small island in South East Asia, has managed to make awe-inspiring strides towards peacebuilding and securing political stability after gaining its independence in 2002 from Indonesia, becoming one of the world’s youngest democracies. My current work focuses on health system strengthening at primary health care level from a mentor perspective in one of its most fragile aspects: nutrition. According to the “2020 Global Hunger Index” alarming levels of hunger have been identified in Timor-Leste (1), placing it as the second world’s hungriest country. The Government of Timor recognizes the importance of treating this matter with the urgency it deserves. They have committed to prioritize the Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 2: End hunger, achieve food security and improved nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture (2) by engaging multiple sectors and creating a high-level National Council for Food Security, Sovereignty and Nutrition. Most organizations focus on nutrition-sensitive strategies in contrast to our approach which heavily invests in supporting nutrition-specific interventions.

The amount of effort the Ministry of Health with support from UN agencies, has put into developing comprehensive IMAM guidelines cannot be denied. Furthermore, it has poured significant resources into primary health care services to scale up CMAM practices. Nevertheless, translating these policies into action has proven to be the issue. Hence our organization focuses on building capacity within the existing workforce to implement these instead of health care service delivery. There is currently a package of high impact nutrition interventions designed to deliver malnutrition screening, treatment and IYCF counselling among under 5 and PLW. The key in fighting malnutrition in Timor ultimately relies on the government and its’ people. Regardless of the availability of guidelines and the systems already in place, adaptations to ensure future programs’ success need to be made. For instance, UN agencies are supportive of trying the simplified protocol for management of wasting due to evident challenges with coverage and access to supplementary foods for MAM treatment. Negotiations have already started and this new approach will be piloted this year. Certainly, the ultimate goal is to increase efficiency and reach a larger vulnerable group of wasted children, for which a simplified dosage of RUTF not based on weight and MUAC-screening-only might be a potential solution to reduce the program’s complexity. Eliminating the need for different supply chains and promoting the use of a single therapeutic product could reduce costs of infrastructure and the administrative workload involved. Even though there is growing evidence that MUAC itself can be used as a non-inferior indicator to measure SAM recovery in comparison to the standard criteria (3) there are still ongoing discussions on the discrepancy between MUAC and WHZ. We cannot deny using this approach as a cost effective measure to increase coverage is tempting and promising, however we should keep in mind the implications of relapse, non-responders and children above two years at high risk of death who might require WHZ screening and higher RUTF dosage interventions to improve growth. Moreover, there is limited evidence on the quality of treatment in non-emergency settings and its long term impact.

Finally, at program level periodical analysis of programs’ outcomes are critically important in order to build strong evidence of the impact CMAM has on the community. M&E forms contribute not only to showcase meaningful progress achieved, but also challenging areas of the program which may need future improvement. Sadly, a lack of data surveillance challenges the adherence to SPEHERE standards to monitor children’s progress.

Although ending acute malnutrition is a daunting task to undertake, several countries have shown substantial success. This has required tackling a variety of socio-economic and cultural factors together with consideration of crucial elements such as strong coordination and community mobilization. The most recent champion of reducing malnutrition trends has been Peru, which decided to focus on evidence-based interventions on conditional cash transfers and the incorporation of health and nutrition into the school curriculum. Previously, Thailand adopted a community based approach investing in the first 1000 days of a child’s life to end the hunger crisis, whilst Vietnam placed strong emphasis on well-structured family programs and ensuring girl’s education. The most clear example of a multisectoral approach is Brazil, which chose to address basic socio-economic determinants of undernutrition, implementing policies targeting inequality and providing universal access to education, sanitation, and healthcare. Clearly, there is no one single strategy for the fight against hunger. Nevertheless, a variety of critical factors have been addressed with different approaches which has ultimately contributed to improving global nutrition status. All of the above examples illustrate that political stability and commitment to combating malnutrition are vital priorities, along with other key factors such as resource allocation, strong multisectoral leadership in implementation, and M&E. It would be interesting for national policy makers to reflect on how different food security and nutrition approaches could be adapted to direct Timor in the right direction for providing a better future for its children and making sure they thrive to their fullest potential.

IMAM: Integrated Management of Acute Malnutrition
CMAM: Community Management of Acute Malnutrition
IYCF: Infant and Young Child Feeding 
PLW: Pregnant and Lactating Women
RUSF: Ready-to-Use-Supplementary-Foods
RUTF: Ready-to-Use-Therapeutic-Foods
MAM: Moderate-Acute-Malnutrition
SAM: Severe-Acute-Malnutrition
MUAC: Midd-Upper-Arm-Circumference
WHZ: Weight-for-Height-Z score
M&E: Monitoring and Evaluation

Between 2015 and 2020, The State of Acute Malnutrition was supported by theNo Wasted LivesCoalition, an interagency effort between Action Against Hunger, the Children’s Investment Fund Foundation, the European Commission Directorate-General for Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection (ECHO), the innocent foundation, the International Rescue Committee (IRC), UNICEF, and World Food Programme (WFP). The CMAM 2.0: Reinventing Community Management of Acute Malnutrition grant supported by the Children’s Investment Fund Foundation that financed the No Wasted Lives initiative, is now closed.

Poorly coordinated mechanisms between inpatient and outpatient treatment, which may well be a potential key factor affecting mortality or relapse to complicated SAM after discharge.
An unreliable supply of therapeutic and supplementary foods available, especially in outpatient care settings. RUSF treatment for MAM and Supercereal for PLW have currently been out of stock for the whole country for over 18 months. RUTF treatment has been fairly consistent during the COVID-19 crisis. Nevertheless, there have been times in the past where SAM patients were not able to get full rations due to insufficient stock of therapeutic foods.
A weak M&E system with limited national coverage
In order for our organization to better support quality care and empower community engagement in local health services, we are committed to addressing the first two of these difficulties at the program level by:
Providing comprehensive upskilling training packages, field-based technical assistance and mentoring to ensure acutely malnourished children are identified, reporting and monitoring data, treatment delivery and family counselling at health facilities. Not only are we expecting to achieve high standards of CMAM practices, but also to develop leadership in the nutrition programming sector, which currently has a weak teaching curriculum for wasting management.
Strengthening the referral system; a project focusing on improving the critical gap between decentralized outpatient care for children with appetite and no medical complications that can be managed in the community and inpatient care for those who need it. Even though, operational structure for referring uncomplicated SAM from the national hospital back to the community where rehabilitation phase should follow exists, a clear lack of implementation is hindering a complete recovery and most likely contributing to undetected relapse.

Moreover, there is limited evidence on the quality of treatment in non-emergency settings and its long term impact.

M&E forms contribute not only to showcase meaningful progress achieved, but also challenging areas of the program which may need future improvement. Sadly, a lack of data surveillance challenges the adherence to SPEHERE standards to monitor children’s progress.
